intro: Cheiranthus corinthius, commonly known as the Corinthian candytuft, is a flowering plant native to the Mediterranean region. It is a member of the Brassicaceae family, which includes other well-known plants like cabbages and mustards. The plant produces small, white or pink flowers that bloom in early spring, often in clusters at the ends of the stems. Its leaves are lance-shaped and covered in fine hairs, and it prefers well-drained soils in full sun. Cheiranthus corinthius is often cultivated as an ornamental plant for its delicate, showy flowers.
